title: 103_s895
content: The Act titled "Historic Rehabilitation Tax Credit Expansion Act of 1993" addresses the treatment of rehabilitation credit under passive activity limitations. The Act "Historic Rehabilitation Tax Credit Expansion Act of 1993" modifies the rules for rental real estate activities under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It limits the offset for rental real estate activities to $25,000, with a reduction based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeding $100,000. The phaseout does not apply to low-income housing credits. The Act limits the deduction equivalent to $25,000 for certain credits under section 42, with a reduction based on passive activity losses. The $55,500 limit for rehabilitation credits applies after the application of subparagraph (A) and paragraph (1) for the portion of the passive activity credit attributable to the rehabilitation credit under section 47. Adjusted gross income for purposes of paragraph (2)(A) shall be determined without regard to certain amounts includable/excludable from gross income or allowable as deductions. Conforming amendments are made to section 469(i)(4) of the Code. The tax code is being amended to reduce certain exemption amounts for surviving spouses. Section 469(i)(5)(A) is also amended to change the amount from $25,000 to $12,500 in certain subparagraphs. The tax code amendments reduce exemption amounts for surviving spouses and change certain amounts in subsections. Effective May 5, 1993, the changes apply to property placed in service in taxable years ending after that date. The tax code amendments reduce exemption amounts for surviving spouses and change certain amounts in subsections. Effective May 5, 1993, the changes apply to property placed in service in taxable years ending after that date. Rehabilitation credit allowed to offset portion of alternative minimum tax. The tax code amendments allow the rehabilitation investment credit to offset a portion of the alternative minimum tax. The limitation under paragraph (1) shall be reduced by the credit allowed for the taxable year, excluding the rehabilitation investment tax credit. The minimum tax offset amount is determined as 25 percent of the tentative. The rehabilitation investment tax credit is a portion of the regular investment tax credit, with specific percentages based on the type of corporation. A conforming amendment was made to Section 38(d) regarding components of the investment credit. The new amendment adds a special rule for the rehabilitation investment tax credit, treating it as used last. This change applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1992.
